FacilityName: Smithfield Packaged Meats Corp. - Cumming, GA
FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Mechanical Integrity NDT performed by Acuren

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
This submittal informs all interested parties that this facility is participating in the OSHA Process
Safety Management (PSM) program defined in 29 CFR 1910.119 and the EPA Risk Management
Program (RMP) defined in 40 CFR Part 68. These programs provide for the implementation of detailed
prevention and response procedures when storing and handling hazardous chemicals. The program objectives are to ensure worker and public safety and to provide environmental protection.

Anhydrous ammonia is the only substance at the facility that is regulated under the PSM and RMP
programs. This is the same type of ammonia commonly sprayed on fields by farmers to fertilize crops.
Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant throughout the plant to maintain desired meat
temperatures in coolers, freezers and working areas. Expelling heat caused from altering the ammonia between a liquid and a gas state creates refrigeration in the facility. This refrigeration system consists of a series of compressors, condensers, evaporators, vessels, piping and valves.

The offsite consequences of analysis was determined utilizing RMP comp and the population data is
based upon information pulled from Marplot on 06/18/2015. How to determine the WCS & ARS was
derived from the EPA document, Risk Management Program guidance for offsite consequences of
analysis (1999).

The WCS is based upon the loss of the single largest vessel filled to 80%. The site location utilizes administrative controls during the ammonia charging process to prevent the filling of this vessel beyond 80% full.Prior to this filing the capacity of this vessel had been calculated incorrectly. Fortunately, the true impact on the environment and the community (albeit highly unlikely to occur) is less than previously reported.

The ammonia refrigeration system is operated with a variety of safety devices employed within the
system, included are: high and low level automated shutdown systems and high and

low pressure automated shutdown systems. Alarm systems are utilized to provide early detection of problems within the system before shutdowns occur.

This facilities emergency response program is an action plan to respond to and resolve incidents
Associated with the ammonia refrigeration system. The Fire Department / Hazmat Team will be notified so that they can provide assistance during an incident. If it is necessary to contact the public regarding an
Ammonia release, the local fire department will be contacted to coordinate with the police department. The police department will notify residents and business locations.

Section 1.17c previously reported the onsite quantity of Anhydrous Ammonia as being 35028 pounds. This figure is the Maximum intended inventory for the facility, not the actual quantity of Anhydrous Ammonia. The actual quantity of Anhydrous Ammonia on site is 25,261 pounds.

This facility has not had a reportable release in the past five years.

The facility utilizes Process Hazard Analysis, Compliance Audits, Pre-Startup Safety Reviews,
Mechanical Integrity inspections, Preventative Maintenance activity, equipment inspections, and training to ensure mitigation and control of potential incidents.

The facility will make changes to the system and train as necessary to resolve items noted during
the Process Hazard Analysis, Compliance Audit, Pre-Startup Safety Reviews, and Mechanical Integrity
inspections to improve the safety of the system. Changes will be placed on an action list, evaluated, and
implemented in a timely manner.
